posts.name: Einav Bar-Nir
posts.cooked:
Hi everyone, we just finished competing at Israel District 1 (D-Bug #3316 ), it was a tough but successful competition and we learned a lot - we want to warn teams of the tough defense they might face.

We are using the SDS MK4  swerve drive with NEO motors.

During the qualifications we faced lots of defense, including multiple robots on multiple occasions driving (climbing) over our bumpers and on to our robot.

During the quarterfinals we faced the most damage, a robot drove over us, on one of our swerve modules NEOs and broke it completely (see pictures). Luckily we were able to quickly swap the entire module and learned we have to protect it better for our upcoming competitions.

We want to recommend other swerve teams to protect somehow their modules (and bring extra modules, learn to swap quickly). Teams that are playing defense please try avoiding driving over others.

posts.name: Christian Piper
posts.cooked: We had a similar issue during our Ramp Riot offseason competition this year. We actually cracked the housings where the bolts are on around half of our motors. We didn’t have any extra motors on hand, so superglue was a interesting alternative .This year, we decided to lift our bumpers up to help cover the modules. Almost the entire module is behind the bumper, preventing this issue. We looked at some kind of 3D printed cover, but considering the forces, it would likely not be able to protect the motor from impacts enough to justify it.

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
This was a big problem in 2019 where you could get pushed under the cutouts of the cargo ship.

Saw lots of teams at Houston with guards around their modules. Here is one that looked particularly well done:

posts.name: waialua3:59
posts.cooked: One of our swerve modules got the power wires pulled out from a defensive robot intake ripping it out in QF#1 of our comp last week. Looking at putting something over each module as well.

I am looking at your robot pictures and your general design looks similar to what we are doing (yours looks much better!)

Is there video of your robot in a tion somewhere?

Curious to see how your intake and general game strategy has worked.

Also, opr data show you scoring high hub…are you shooting to the high hub?

Thanks

posts.name: Jonathan Ohayon
posts.cooked:
wildmustang4903:

Curious to see how your intake and general game strategy has worked.

Also, opr data show you scoring high hub…are you shooting to the high hub?

Overall, the robot is pretty similar to 2910’s 2019 bot - the manipulator intakes from one side of the robot and shoots from the other side. There’s place for two balls inside the manipulator to keep it simple, which are left quite loose and pushed to the roller to release.

Strategy was to shoot only from the fender, because it’s the simplest option available. Indeed we shoot to the high hub (technically able to shoot to the lower one too but we didn’t implement it). Together with the swerve this makes the bot a pretty good combination of simple and quick which allowed us to do a good amount of cycles per game.

As to how it worked, we ranked 5th and ended up as semi-finalists as the 4th alliance captains. Honestly I was quite impressed with the team’s performance in the competition and they gave a good fight to the number 1 alliance in the semis, and I’m really proud of the team’s achievements!
